awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multilayer Co-extrusion Processing of Thermally Conductive Polymer Nanocomposites
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymer composites are materials systems with two or more components where the resulting properties can be tailored by the choice and placement of the individual materials during processing.  Polymers are normally poor thermal conductors, but when combined with thermally conductive nanofillers, can result in a polymer composite with desirable conductivity for applications such as microelectronic packaging, substrates for LED-lighting, and solar panel seals. Multilayer co-extrusion, a novel manufacturing technology, provides a promising route to fabricate polymer composites of desirable architecture and properties. Through rational materials design, advanced manufacturing, and structure-property measurements, this award identifies key factors that affect heat conduction in polymer composites and establishes a polymer processing approach to manufacture thermally conductive nanocomposites for applications with significant socio-economic impact. This highly interdisciplinary research provides rich education and training opportunities for students of diverse backgrounds from high-school to graduate level. 

Multilayer co-extrusion processing, when combined with proper design of the precursor materials, could produce nanocomposites with desired microstructure - forming a nanofiller percolation network to enable efficient heat conduction. However, several scientific questions remain to be answered, such as optimal nanofiller characteristics, the most effective way to form percolation networks at a low filler loading, and the desired thermal contact morphology. This project aims to fill the knowledge gap through systematic studies covering the entire research loop of designing materials based on fundamental understanding of multiscale thermal transport mechanisms, tuning the manufacturing processes to achieve desired microstructures, and characterizing the thermal conductivity of the resulting composites to obtain new design insights. The collaborative study tests the central hypothesis that well-controlled multilayer co-extrusion processing can produce thermally conductive polymer composites with true percolation networks formed by direct contacts between anisotropic nanofillers and an optimal network morphology with low contact thermal resistance. This research project is a collaboration between a team that explores co-extrusion of multilayer nanocomposites to generate the desired microstructures and a team that characterizes thermal transport properties to provide insights into materials design and performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to leverage multilayer coextrusion technology at Case Western Reserve University to investigate the orientation and percolation behavior of thermally conductive nanoplatelets within nanoconfined spaces. It is posited that, under one-dimensional nanoconfinement (i.e., in nanolayers), nanoplatelets will exhibit a preference for orientation and percolation at significantly lower thresholds compared to bulk nanocomposites. Consequently, this could lead to a substantial enhancement in thermal conductivity along the layer direction. If successful, the project could result in the development of highly thermally conductive yet electrically insulating nanocomposites, which may have promising applications in LED lighting and advanced electronic systems that require stringent thermal management.

The intellectual merit of this project is to pursue a fundamental understanding of the enhanced percolation of thermally conductive nanoplatelets within nanoconfined layers. The microlayer films were fabricated using the multilayer coextrusion technique, as illustrated in Figure 1A. The first system comprised poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) and poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) combined with graphene nanoplatelets (GNP) at a concentration of 10 wt.%, resulting in 50/50 vol.% multilayer films (Figure 1B). By varying the total number of layers and the overall film thickness, the individual layer thickness was adjusted to range from 31 μm down to approximately 1 μm. The second system involved low-density polyethylene (LDPE) and polystyrene-b-poly(ethylene-co-butene)-b-polystyrene (SEBS) combined with hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) at a concentration of 50 wt.% to create multilayer films (Figure 1C). For the 16-layer PVDF/PMMA-GNP10% films, a reduction in individual layer thickness resulted in an increase in in-plane thermal conductivity (Figure 1D). However, the disparity between in-plane and through-plane thermal conductivities was minimal for the PVDF/PMMA-GNP10% multilayer films. To further enhance thermal conductivity, micron-sized hBN nanoplatelets were incorporated into the second multilayer system, achieving a content of 27 wt.% hBN. Notably, the in-plane thermal conductivity rose to 1.9 Wm-1K-1, significantly surpassing the through-plane thermal conductivity of 0.25 Wm-1K-1 (see Figure 1D). This phenomenon can be attributed to the in-plane orientation and improved percolation of hBN nanoplatelets within the confined layers.

The broader impacts of this project encompass education at all levels in polymer science and engineering. Undergraduate students have engaged in this project through research opportunities, while two high school students have participated via science and senior design projects. Through their involvement, they have gained knowledge in multilayer coextrusion technology and the development of thermally conductive polymer nanocomposite films. The insights acquired from this project have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journal publication, presentations at national ACS meetings (2024), and seminars aimed at local industries. These experiences are instrumental in fostering young students' interest in polymer research and preparing them for careers in the scientific field. Ultimately, these thermally conductive multilayer polymer composites are poised to significantly impact the thermal management of various electronic devices.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/26/2025
Modified by: Lei Zhu

Image
  • (A) Schematic multilayer coextrusion technology. Images of (B) poly(vinylidiene fluoride)/poly(methyl methacrylate)-graphene nanoplatelet and (C) low-density polyethylene/polystyrene-b-poly(ethylene-co-butene)-b-polystyrene-BN multilayer films. (D) In-plane and through-plane thermal conductivities.
    Thumawadee Wongwirat and Lei Zhu
    Copyrighted
    Lei Zhu
    Enhanced Thermal Conductivity in Multilayer Nanocomposite Films
